chapter.title: Declarative Hyperlinking
chapter.para: RESTful APIs must be hypertext-driven. JAX-RS currently offers &jaxrs.core.UriBuilder; to simplify URI creation but Jersey adds an additional annotation-based alternative that is described here.

section.title: Dependency
section.para:
To use Declarative Linking you need to add &lit.jersey-media-linking; module to your &lit.pom.xml; file:
<dependency> <groupId>org.glassfish.jersey.media</groupId> <artifactId>jersey-media-linking</artifactId> <version>&version;</version> </dependency>
If you're not using Maven make sure to have all needed dependencies (see &jersey-media-linking;) on the classpath.

section.title: Links in Representations
section.para: Links are added to representations using the @Ref annotation on entity class fields. The Jersey runtime is responsible for injecting the appropriate URI into the field prior to serialization by a message body writer. E.g. consider the following resource and entity classes:

After a call to WidgetsResource#get, the Jersey runtime will inject the value "/context/widgets"
Where /context is the application deployment context. into the returned Widgets instance. If an absolute URI is desired instead of an absolute path then the annotation can be changed to @Ref(resource=WidgetsResource.class, style=ABSOLUTE).

The above usage works nicely when there's already a URI template on a class that you want to reuse. If there's no such template available then you can use a literal value instead of a reference. E.g. the following is equivalent to the earlier example: @Ref(value="widgets", style=ABSOLUTE).

section.title: Binding Template Parameters
section.para: Referenced or literal templates may contain parameters. Two forms of parameters are supported:

listitem.para: URI template parameters, e.g. widgets/{id} where {id} represents a variable part of the URI.
EL expressions, e.g. widgets/${instance.id} where ${instance.id} is an EL expression.

section.para: Parameter values can be extracted from three implicit beans:

listitem.para: Represents the instance of the class that contains the annotated field.
Represents the entity class instance returned by the resource method.
Represents the resource class instance that returned the entity.

section.title: Link Headers
section.para: HTTP Link headers can also be added to responses using annotations. Instead of annotating the fields of an entity class with @Ref, you instead annotate the entity class itself with @LinkHeader. E.g.:

Multiple link headers can be added by use of the @LinkHeaders annotation which can contain multiple @LinkHeader annotations.
